params.name: params
params.description: Constructor parameters.

props.name: view
props.description: Parameters for Node, Port and Edge definitions. Although this is not a required parameter, the vast majority of applications will

props.name: elementsDraggable
props.description: Whether or not elements should be made draggable.

props.name: elementsDroppable
props.description:
If true, elements can be dragged onto other elements and events will be fired.
What you choose to do with that event is up to you.

props.name: id
props.description: Optional id for this renderer. If you provide this you can then subsequently retrieve it via `toolkit.getRenderer(<id>)`.

props.name: refreshAutomatically
props.description: Whether or not to automatically refresh the associated layout whenever a Node is added or deleted.

props.name: enhancedView
props.description: If false, there will be no support for preconfigured parameters or functions in the definitions inside a view. You will want to set this for Angular if you use the 2-way data binding.

props.name: assignPosse
props.description: optional function that, given each node, can return the id of the posse to which the node belongs. a Posse is a group of nodes that should all be dragged together.

props.name: modelLeftAttribute
props.description: Optional; specifies the name of the attribute by which to store the x position of a dragged node of `storePositionsInModel` is true.

props.name: modelTopAttribute
props.description: Optional; specifies the name of the attribute by which to store the y position of a dragged node of `storePositionsInModel` is true.

jsPlumbToolkit.Dialogs.name: jsPlumbToolkit.Dialogs
jsPlumbToolkit.Dialogs.description: A library for providing simple dialogs to use with an instance of the jsPlumb Toolkit.

jsPlumbToolkit.DrawingTools.name: jsPlumbToolkit.DrawingTools
jsPlumbToolkit.DrawingTools.description:
Provides a set of drawing tools to use in conjunction with a Surface in the Toolkit - select, drag, resize.
Everything this tool adds to the UI has an associated CSS class, so you can skin it very easily. There are no
methods on this class - you just construct one with the parameters you need.

params.name: params
params.description: Constructor parameters.

props.name: renderer
props.description: Surface renderer to associate the tools with.

props.name: widthAttribute
props.description: Name of the attribute used to store the node's width in its data.

props.name: heightAttribute
props.description: Name of the attribute used to store the node's height in its data.

props.name: leftAttribute
props.description: Name of the attribute used to store the node's left position in its data.

props.name: topAttribute
props.description: Name of the attribute used to store the node's top position in its data.

Node.name: Node
Node.description:
This is a Node in the Graph. Each Node can have one or more Edges to any other Node; this Edge may be
directed.  A Node may also have zero or more Ports, which themselves may have one or more Edges to other Nodes
or to Ports on other Nodes.

Every Node has an associated *indegree centrality* and *outdegree centrality*. These are measurements of the number
of links to and from the Node. Whenever an Edge is added or removed the indegree and outdegree centrality
values for the Node are recomputed. For further reading we suggest [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centrality#Degree_centrality).

You can instantiate a Node with any type of backing data you wish.  If you supply a String,
that value is assumed to be the Node's ID. If you supply a JSON object, an ID is extracted from that object,
either with the supplied `idFunction`, or, if that is null, by assuming that the ID exists in the JSON as the
`id` member.

params.name: data
params.description: Optional data backing the node. This object can be of any type you like, but if you supply a String, that value will be assumed to be the Node's ID.

params.name: idFunction
params.description: Optional function that can take a Node's data and return its ID. By default this looks for an `id` member in the backing data.

params.name: graph
params.description: Graph the Vertex belongs to.

Port.name: Port
Port.description:
A Port resides on a Node, and may be the source/target of one or more connections. A convenient way to think
of Ports is as the columns in a database table: they belong to a table, but it is the columns themselves that
have relationships with other columns.

Edge.name: Edge
Edge.description:
This is an Edge in the graph.  There can be one or zero of these for every pair of Nodes/Ports in the Graph.  Each Edge has an associated "cost", and may be either bidirectional
or unidirectional.

params.name: params
params.description: Edge parameters.

props.name: data
props.description: Optional backing data for the edge.

props.name: source
props.description: Edge's source.

props.name: target
props.description: Edge's target.

props.name: cost
props.description: Edge's cost. Defaults to 1.

props.name: directed
props.description: Whether or not the Edge is directed. Default is true.

Graph.name: Graph
Graph.description:
A Graph.  Contains a list of Vertex objects, each of which has 0..N Ports, and a list of Edge objects. Every instance
of the jsPlumb Toolkit is backed by an instance of this lass.

A good discussion on Graphs can be found on Wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_(mathematics).

params.name: params
params.description: Constructor parameters. Optional. The Graph class has sensible defaults.

props.name: defaultDirected
props.description: Whether edges are directed by default.

props.name: idFunction
props.description: Function to use to extract an appropriate ID from the JSON for a give node. Defaults to returning the 'id' property of the JSON.

props.name: enableSubgraphs
props.description: If true, Nodes are Graphs themselves, and can have child Nodes. If you enable this then you cannot use slashes (/) in your Node ids, as they will be treated as components of a path to a Node in a nested Graph.

props.name: defaultCost
props.description: Default cost for Edges.

props.name: portSeparator
props.description: The character(s) used to separate ports from nodes in port ids.

jsPlumbToolkit directive..name: jsPlumbToolkit directive.
jsPlumbToolkit directive..description:
Provides an angular directive to create an instance of the Toolkit. Params discussed here are
provided as attributes to the element, for instance:

<jsplumb-toolkit jtk-id="myToolkit" params="SomeController.myToolkitParams" .../>

Note that of course since they are attributes then their real types are String, but the types discussed
here are the required types of objects resolved through Angular's DI.

params.name: jtk-id
params.description:
ID of the Toolkit to create. You will want to use this if you need to subsequently
access the Toolkit instance from the `jsPlumbService`.

params.name: surface-id
params.description: Optional ID of the Surface widget.

params.name: params
params.description: Optional parameters for the Toolkit constructor.

params.name: renderParams
params.description:
Optional parameters for the Surface widget. It is highly likely you will
want to supply something here.

params.name: data
params.description: Optional data to load at create time.

params.name: init
params.description:
Optional function to call back at the end of the Toolkit's `link` function.
This function is passed the current scope (which contains the Toolkit and Surface objects), as well as the
element into which the Toolkit was rendered, and the attributes that were set on the `jsplumb-toolkit` element.

jsPlumb Palette directive.name: jsPlumb Palette directive
jsPlumb Palette directive.description: Provides an Angular directive for configuring a set of droppable nodes for a Surface.

params.name: typeExtractor
params.description: Function used to extract the type of a dropped node from the element that was dropped.

params.name: dataGenerator
params.description: Optional function that can prepare some initial data for a dropped node.

params.name: dragOptions
params.description:
Options for the drag. If these are omitted then some sensible (at least, what
jsPlumb considers sensible) defaults are used.

jsPlumbToolkitInstance.name: jsPlumbToolkitInstance
jsPlumbToolkitInstance.description:
An instance of the jsPlumb Toolkit.  Each instance is backed by a `Graph`, and has zero or more `Renderer`s attached.

#### Creating an instance
You create an instance of the jsPlumb Toolkit via the static method `jsPlumbToolkit.newInstance(params)`. The contents of `params` are
any valid constructor parameters as detailed here.
#### Rendering data
An instance of the jsPlumb Toolkit does not itself handle rendering the data to your UI; to do that, you must call the `render`
method of your Toolkit instance:
```
var myToolkit = jsPlumbToolkit.newInstance();
var aRenderer = myToolkit.render({
  container:"someElementId",
  ...other params, possibly..
});
```
#### Operating on the dataset
In general, you will operate on the dataset via the `jsPlumbToolkitInstance` object, because any attached `Renderers` will
for the most part sort themselves out based on the data model. Occasionally you will want to perform some view-specific
operation such as highlighting a Path, or hiding some Nodes, etc.  These sorts of operations are executed on the
`Renderer` and not on the Toolkit object.

params.name: params
params.description: Constructor parameters

props.name: idFunction
props.description:
Optional function to use to extract an id from a Node's data. The default
is to retrieve the `id` property.

props.name: typeFunction
props.description:
Optional function to use to extract a type identifier from a Node's data.
The default is to retrieve the property defined by `typeProperty`.

props.name: typeProperty
props.description:
Optional name of the property that identifies a Node's type from its data.
The default is `type`.

props.name: edgeIdFunction
props.description:
Optional function to use to extract an id from an Edge's data. The
default is to retrieve the `id` property.

props.name: edgeTypeFunction
props.description:
Optional function to use to extract a type identifier from an Edge's data.
The default is to retrieve the property defined by `edgeTypeProperty`.

props.name: edgeTypeProperty
props.description:
Optional name of the property that identifies an Edge's type from its data.
The default is `type`.

props.name: portIdFunction
props.description:
Optional function to use to extract an id from a Port's data. The
default is to retrieve the `id` property.

props.name: portTypeFunction
props.description:
Optional function to use to extract a type identifier from a Port's
data. The default is to retrieve the `type` property.

props.name: model
props.description: Model of Node, Edge and Port definitions.  See documentation.

props.name: beforeConnect
props.description:
Optional function that will be called prior to any edge being
established (either programmatically or via the mouse). It is passed the (source, target) of the proposed edge
and if it returns anything other than boolean true, the edge is aborted.
If not supplied, the default behaviour of this function is to honor the `allowLoopback`, `allowNodeLoopback`
and `maxConnections` parameters on any Node or Port definitions you supplied to this Toolkit via the `model`.

props.name: beforeMoveConnection
props.description:
Optional function that will be called prior to any existing edge
being moved (either programmatically or via the mouse). It is passed the source and target of the existing edge,
as well as the edge itself, and if it returns anything other than boolean true, the edge move is aborted.
If not supplied, the default behaviour of this function is to honor the `allowLoopback`, `allowNodeLoopback` and
`maxConnections` parameters on any Node or Port definitions you supplied to this Toolkit via the `model`.

props.name: beforeStartConnect
props.description:
Optional function that will be called prior to an edge being
established. This is different from `beforeConnect` in that this function is called right at the beginning of a
connection drag by attached renderers, and the function is given the node/port that is the source, plus the edge
type. If you return false the Edge is aborted. Otherwise your return value is used as the Edge data.

props.name: beforeDetach
props.description:
Optional function that can be used to override connection detachment from
the mouse. The function is given (source, target, edge) and is expected to return true to confirm the detach
should occur. Any other return value will abort the detach.

props.name: beforeStartDetach
props.description:
Optional function that can be used to override connection detachment
from the mouse. Distinct from `beforeDetach` in that this function is called as soon as the user begins to drag.
The function is given (source, target, edge) and is expected to return true to confirm the detach should occur.
Any other return value will abort the detach.

props.name: nodeFactory
props.description:
Function to use to generate data for a new Node. Default is to create an
object with an `id` property.

props.name: edgeFactory
props.description:
Function to use to generate data for a new Edge. Default is to create an
object with an `id` property.

props.name: portFactory
props.description:
Function to use to generate data for a new Port. Default is to create an
object with an `id` property.

props.name: portExtractor
props.description:
Optional function to call whenever a Node is added; it extracts, from
the Node's data, any Ports that are associated with the Node.

props.name: autoSave
props.description:
Whether or not to automatically save the dataset when changes occur. You
must supply the `saveUrl` property if you set this to true.

props.name: saveUrl
props.description: Url to use when saving automatically.

props.name: onAutoSaveSuccess
props.description: Optional function to call on autoSave success.

props.name: onAutoSaveError
props.description: Optional function to call on autoSave error.

props.name: doNotUpdateOriginalData
props.description:
If true, won't try to update the original data when a
Node/Edge is removed.

props.name: maxSelectedEdges
props.description:
Optional limit for the number of edges allowed to be selected at any
one time.

props.name: maxSelectedNodes
props.description:
Optional limit for the number of nodes allowed to be selected at any
one time.

props.name: selectionCapacityPolicy
props.description:
Optional selection capacity policy. See
`setSelectionCapacityPolicy` docs.

jsPlumbToolkit.Widgets.Lasso.name: jsPlumbToolkit.Widgets.Lasso
jsPlumbToolkit.Widgets.Lasso.description:
The Lasso widget allows users to select an area with the mouse. You will not typically need to interact with
this widget, or create one manually, since the `Surface` widget handles all of that for you.

params.name: params
params.description: Parameters for the widget.

props.name: pageLocation
props.description: Function that can return a page location for an event.

props.name: canvas
props.description: DOM Element on which the Lasso will operate.

props.name: invert
props.description:
If true, the lasso is drawn as blank space over the selected area, with
elements filling the excluded area.

props.name: onStart
props.description: Optional function to call at the start of a lasso operation.

props.name: onEnd
props.description: Optional function to call at the end of a lasso operation.

props.name: onSelect
props.description: Optional function to call on each mousemove during a lasso operation.

props.name: filter
props.description: Optional CSS selector identifying elements that should be filtered and not begin a lasso operation.

Layouts.AbstractLayout.name: Layouts.AbstractLayout
Layouts.AbstractLayout.description:
The parent for all layouts. This class maintains an array of element positions and
sizes, and provides the key methods for executing layout functionality.  When using the Toolkit
you will not ordinarily need to interact directly with a layout, but if you write your own layout
then you need to extend this class and implement the abstract methods you need.

##### Custom Layouts

The general syntax for writing a custom layout is to call `AbstractLayout`'s constructor and assign the
return value to a variable:

```
jsPlumbToolkit.Layouts["MyLayout"] = function(params) {
  var _super = jsPlumbToolkit.Layouts.AbstractLayout.apply(this, arguments);
  ...
 };
```

##### Lifecycle

The lifecycle of a layout - controlled by this class - is as follows:

- `begin(_jsPlumbToolkit, parameters)` This is an optional method.
- `step(_jsPlumbToolkit, parameters)` This is called repeatedly until your code has indicated that the layout is complete (see below)
- `end(_jsPlumbToolkit, parameters)` Also an optional method.

##### Layout Completion

You are required to inform the superclass when your layout is complete, via this method:

```
_super.setDone(true);
```

#### Other Optional Methods
Your layout can implement several optional methods should you need finer grained control of the lifecycle:

- `_nodeAdded` - Notification that a new Node was added to the dataset.
- `_nodeRemoved` - Notification that a new Node was added to the dataset.
- `_nodeMoved` - Notification that a Node was moved.

params.name: params
params.description: Constructor parameters

props.name: draggable
props.description: Whether or not elements should be draggable.

props.name: dragOptions
props.description: Drag options to set on individual elements.

Layouts.EmptyLayout.name: Layouts.EmptyLayout
Layouts.EmptyLayout.description: A layout that does very little beyond implementing the functions present in the layout API

Layouts.Mistletoe.name: Layouts.Mistletoe
Layouts.Mistletoe.description:
Mistletoe layout grows on another layout and does nothing except override lifecycle events and then
update itself once all the hard work has been done. It is used by the Miniview component.

params.name: params.layout
params.description: The layout on which to leech.

Layouts.AbsoluteBackedLayout.name: Layouts.AbsoluteBackedLayout
Layouts.AbsoluteBackedLayout.description:
Mixin for layouts that have an absolute backing.  This includes, of course, the `Absolute` layout,
which is actually just a direct reference to this class.
The default behaviour is to look for a `left` and `top` member in each node, but you
can supply a `locationFunction` parameter to the constructor to derive your own
position from each node.

params.name: params
params.description: Constructor parameters

props.name: locationFunction
props.description:
Takes a Node and returns an [x,y] array indicating
the location of the given Node. The backing data for a Node is available as the `data` property.

Layouts.Absolute.name: Layouts.Absolute
Layouts.Absolute.description:
This layout places elements with absolute positioning. The default is to look for a `left` and `top`
member in each node, but you can supply your own `locationFunction` parameter to the constructor to
derive your own position from each node.

params.name: params
params.description: Constructor parameters

props.name: locationFunction
props.description: Takes node data and returns an [x,y] array indicating the location of the given Node.

Layouts.AbstractHierarchicalLayout.name: Layouts.AbstractHierarchicalLayout
Layouts.AbstractHierarchicalLayout.description:
Mixin for hierarchical layouts (those that expect a root node). This class takes care of
putting `rootNode` and `root` values in the parameters that are subsequently passed into the
various lifecycle methods of the layout. The root node is the first node found in the Graph (ie the first node
you added to the Graph)

params.name: params
params.description: Constructor parameters

props.name: ignoreLoops
props.description:
Whether or not to ignore loops in the layout. When false,
an exception will be thrown if a loop is found.

props.name: getRootNode
props.description:
Optional function that can return the node that should be the root
of the hierarchy. If this is not provided then the first Node in the Toolkit is used.

props.name: getChildNodes
props.description:
Optional function to be used to get child nodes for each node. The
default is simply to look for Nodes that are targets of an Edge from the focus Node.

Layouts.Hierarchical.name: Layouts.Hierarchical
Layouts.Hierarchical.description: Provides a hierarchical tree layout, oriented either horizontally or vertically.

params.name: params
params.description: Constructor parameters

props.name: orientation
props.description: Orientation of the layout. Valid values are `"vertical"` and `"horizontal"`.

props.name: padding
props.description: Array of padding values for x and y axes. Default is `[60, 60]`.

params.name: [compress
params.description:
= false] If true, the layout will use a regular spacing between each node and its parent. Otherwise
the layout pushes each node down by the maximum size of some element in that level of the hierarchy. For complex
hierarchies in which any given node may have children, that is better. But for simple hierarchies, setting
`compress` can give good results.

jsPlumbToolkit.Layouts.Spring.name: jsPlumbToolkit.Layouts.Spring
jsPlumbToolkit.Layouts.Spring.description:
Provides a force directed graph layout in which connections between nodes are modelled as springs. By default, this Layout
switches on the magnetizer, to ensure that no nodes overlap.  You can switch it off via the `magnetize:false` argument
in the `layout` parameters of a `render` call.

params.name: params
params.description: Constructor parameters

props.name: absoluteBacked
props.description: Whether or not the layout will fall back to absolute positions stored in the data.

props.name: stiffness
props.description: A measure of how stiff the springs are modelled to be.

props.name: repulsion
props.description: A measure of how much each Node repels every other Node.

props.name: damping
props.description: A measure of how quickly the system settles. This parameter should always be set to a value less than 1. A higher value for this parameter will cause the layout to take longer to run.

props.name: limit
props.description: The threshold below which the system is assumed to be stable enough for the layout to exit. This value is related to the values you provide for stiffness and repulsion (and damping, of course, but to a lesser extent).

jsPlumbToolkit.Renderers.Miniview.name: jsPlumbToolkit.Renderers.Miniview
jsPlumbToolkit.Renderers.Miniview.description:
The Miniview widget. A single instance of this is paired with an instance of Surface.

The fundamental difference between this and a Surface is that a Miniview does not draw connections. Plus, it
calculates its own zoom based on the ratio of the size of its viewport compared to the size of the viewport of
the related Surface. In reality, a Miniview could reside inside an element that is much bigger than that in which
the related Surface resides, but it does not seem likely that that would normally be the case.

The Miniview widget provides a floating window that represents a scaled version of the viewport of the related
Surface. Dragging this window around causes the related Surface to pan.  Resizing (via grabbing a corner and
dragging) the window causes the Surface to zoom in/out (within its allowed zoom range).

All of the visual aspects of the Miniview can be controlled via CSS, and you can provide a custom CSS class
to allow you to target the styles for an individual Miniview more easily.

You do not create a Miniview directly - you either specify its parameters in a `render` call on a `jsPlumbToolkitInstance`,
or you call `createMiniview` on an existing `Surface`.

jsPlumbToolkit.Model.name: jsPlumbToolkit.Model
jsPlumbToolkit.Model.description:
A Model describes the appearance and behaviour of a set of Nodes, Edges and Ports. You do not
create one of these directly; instead you pass a definition to a `jsPlumbToolkit.render` or
`jsPlumbToolkit.newInstance()` call. Although the Model has the same syntax in each context, you are
encouraged to configure model-specific things in the Model you pass to the `newInstance` method (such as,
which Nodes/Ports can be connected to which others, what is the maximum number of connections, etc), and
view-specific things (such as css classes, paint styles, connector appearance etc) to the model you pass to
the `render` method. The `render` method automatically merges in a Node/Port/Edge definition from a Model
defined on the associated Toolkit, if there is one.

params.name: params
params.description: Model parameters

props.name: nodes
props.description: Node definitions.

props.name: edges
props.description: Edge definitions.

props.name: ports
props.description: Port definitions.

params.name: _jsPlumb
params.description:
An instance of jsPlumb on which to register associated Connection and Endpoint types.
Only the Surface widget provides this. The Toolkit instance creates a Model but it is headless.

params.name: params
params.description: Constructor parameters

props.name: canvas
props.description: The element to apply pan/zoom to.

props.name: viewport
props.description: The element that will act as the viewport for the canvas.

props.name: bind
props.description: Function that can bind to an event on an element.

props.name: unbind
props.description: Function that can unbind from an event on an element.

props.name: height
props.description: A function that can return the height for some element.

props.name: width
props.description: A function that can return the width for some element.

props.name: offset
props.description: A function that can return {left:.., top:..} for some element

props.name: id
props.description: A function that can return an id for some element.

props.name: domElement
props.description:
A function that can translate between objects referenced by the widget and DOM elements. It might be
the case that no tranlation is required - you deal only in DOM elements. But also you might use this with jQuery,
and pass around jQuery selectors. So this function just normalises elements. If not supplied, the default function
assumes elements are already DOM elements.

props.name: events
props.description: Optional map of event handlers

props.name: zoom
props.description: Optional function callback for when zoom changes.

props.name: pan
props.description: Optional function callback for when pan changes.

props.name: mousedown
props.description: Optional function callback for mousedown event.

props.name: mouseup
props.description: Optional function callback for mouseup event.

props.name: mousemove
props.description: Optional function callback for mousemove event.

props.name: maybeZoom
props.description: Optional interceptor for zoom. Returning false prevents zoom from occurring.

props.name: transformOrigin
props.description: Optional function callback for transform origin change. This is given the [x,y] (in percent) of the new origin, and the [left, top] (in absolute values) of the canvas.

props.name: clamp
props.description: Whether to clamp when panning such that there is always content visible.

props.name: clampZoom
props.description: Whether to clamp when zooming such that there is always content visible.

props.name: clampToBackground
props.description: Whether or not to clamp to the background image. This flag means the widget will always ensure at least some of the background is visible. See `clampToBackgroundExtents` for a variant of this.

props.name: clampToBackgroundExtents
props.description: Clamps movement so that when zoomed out, the background image always fills the viewport.

props.name: onBackgroundReady
props.description: Optional callback to hit when the background image has loaded.

props.name: panDistance
props.description: How far, in pixels, to pan on pan nudge.

props.name: zoom
props.description: Initial zoom for the widget.

props.name: enableWheelZoom
props.description: Whether or not wheel zoom is enabled.

props.name: wheelFilter
props.description: Optional function to call to check if wheel zooming should be enabled for the current event target.

props.name: enablePan
props.description: Whether or not pan is enabled.

props.name: enablePanButtons
props.description: Whether or not wheel pan buttons are drawn and enabled.

props.name: enableAnimation
props.description: Enable animations for panning. Defaults to true.

props.name: enabled
props.description: Whether or not the widget is enabled, ie. responding to mouse input.

props.name: background
props.description: Optional background image parameters

props.name: url
props.description: URL for the background. Required for both single images and tiled backgrounds.

props.name: type
props.description: "simple" or "tiled" - the type of background.

props.name: tileSize
props.description: For tiled backgrounds, provides the width and height of tiles. Every tile is assumed to have these dimensions, even if the tile has whitespace in it.

props.name: width
props.description: Required for tiled backgrounds. Indicates the width of the full image.

props.name: height
props.description: Required for tiled backgrounds. Indicates the height of the full image.

props.name: maxZoom
props.description: Required for tiled backgrounds. Indicates the maximum zoom level. Zoom starts at 0 - fully zoomed out - and increases in integer values from there. Eash successive zoom level is twice the zoom of the previous level, meaning two times as many tiles in each direction.

props.name: filter
props.description: Optional filter that will be called on down event, with the event target and the event. Returning true from this function means the widget should respond to the event.

props.name: padding
props.description:
Optional values for padding in the x/y axes to leave around the content. This is only of any use if you have disabled panning via mouse drag,
since in that case the user sees only scroll bars and has no way of navigating beyond the content. Some padding makes the UI nicer to use. Default is [0,0].

props.name: consumeRightClick
props.description: Useful for development: set this to false if you don't want the widget to consume context menu clicks.

props.name: smartMinimumZoom
props.description: Means that the lower zoom bound refers to a multiple of the content bounds, not the viewport.

params.name: [params.zoomRange=[0.05,
params.description: 3] ] Zoom range for the widget.

Path.name: Path
Path.description: Models the path between two Nodes/Ports, which consists of a series of [Node/Port, Edge] pairs.

params.name: params
params.description: Constructor params

props.name: toolkit
props.description: jsPlumb Toolkit instance to which this Selection belongs.

props.name: generator
props.description:
Optional function that can be called to fill the selection. You'd use this
when you are rendering individual selections and you need to be able to refresh the whole view based on some
change in the data model.

props.name: onClear
props.description: Optional function to call when the selection is cleared.

jsPlumbToolkit.Support.name: jsPlumbToolkit.Support
jsPlumbToolkit.Support.description:
Support functionality for working with existing jsPlumb instances in the Toolkit. Using the `ingest` method in this
class, you can ingest an existing jsPlumb instance into a new instance of the Toolkit; this for many people may
prove to be a logical upgrade path from their existing jsPlumb code.

When you ingest an existing jsPlumb instance, its `Container` is configured to be a `Surface` widget, which makes
it pannable and zoomable, and the set of Nodes and Edges it is managing are loaded into the Toolkit's data model.

Surface.name: Surface
Surface.description:
A widget that provides pan/zoom functionality, as well as the ability to load/store state in the browser.
You do not construct an instance of this class manually: you obtain an instance of Surface via a call to the `render`
method on a `jsPlumbToolkitInstance`. But the supported parameters to that `render` method are whatever is supported by
the Surface constructor, as documented here.

params.name: params
params.description: Constructor parameters

props.name: container
props.description: Element to convert into a Surface.

props.name: elementsDraggable
props.description: Whether or not elements in the Surface should be draggable.

props.name: dragOptions
props.description: Options for draggable nodes.

props.name: events
props.description: Optional event bindings. See documentation.

props.name: miniview
props.description: Optional miniview configuration.

props.name: container
props.description: Container for the miniview.  An Element, an element id, or a selector.

props.name: initiallyVisible
props.description: Whether or not the miniview should be invisible until some data is loaded.

props.name: mode
props.description: Mode to initialize the Surface in.

props.name: panDistance
props.description: How far a pan nudge should move the UI (in pixels).

props.name: zoom
props.description: Initial zoom for the widget.

props.name: enablePan
props.description: Whether or not panning (via mouse drag) is enabled.

props.name: enableWheelZoom
props.description: Whether or not zooming with the mouse wheel is enabled.

props.name: enableAnimation
props.description: Enable animations for panning. Defaults to true.

props.name: wheelFilter
props.description: Optional CSS selector representing elements that should not respond to wheel zoom.

props.name: panFilter
props.description:
Optional; either a CSS selector representing elements that should allow a pan event to begin, or a function that will be
                         called with the event target. Returning true from this function means the widget should respond to the event.

props.name: wheelSensitivity
props.description: How many pixels each click of the mouse wheel represents when zooming. Note that this value, while expressed in pixels, is mapped in a variety of ways depending on the browser.

props.name: enablePanButtons
props.description: Whether or not to show the pan nudge buttons on the borders of the widgets.

props.name: padding
props.description:
Optional values for padding in the x/y axes to leave around the content. This is only of any use if you have disabled panning via mouse drag,
since in that case the user sees only scroll bars and has no way of navigating beyond the content. Some padding makes the UI nicer to use. Default is [0,0].

props.name: lassoFilter
props.description: Optional selector for elements on which a mousedown should not cause the lasso to activate.

props.name: lassoInvert
props.description: If true, the lasso operates by masking the unselected parts of the display.

props.name: lassoSelectionFilter
props.description: Optional function that can be used to filter the set of nodes a lasso drag is selecting. The function is given each candidate Node in turn; returning false indicates the Node should not be selected.

props.name: consumeRightClick
props.description: Useful for development: set this to false if you don't want the widget to consume context menu clicks.

props.name: stateHandle
props.description: If supplied, this will be used as the default handle for state save/restore operations.

props.name: clamp
props.description: Whether to clamp when panning such that there is always content visible.

props.name: clampZoom
props.description: Whether to clamp when zooming such that there is always content visible.

props.name: clampToBackground
props.description: If a background is set, whether to clamp movement such that some part of the background is always visible.

props.name: clampToBackgroundExtents
props.description: If a background is set, whether to clamp movement such that the background fills as much of the viewport as it can.

props.name: background
props.description: Optional background image parameters

props.name: url
props.description: URL for the background. Required for both single images and tiled backgrounds.

props.name: type
props.description: "simple" or "tiled" - the type of background.

props.name: tileSize
props.description: For tiled backgrounds, provides the width and height of tiles. Every tile is assumed to have these dimensions, even if the tile has whitespace in it.

props.name: width
props.description: Required for tiled backgrounds. Indicates the width of the full image.

props.name: height
props.description: Required for tiled backgrounds. Indicates the height of the full image.

props.name: maxZoom
props.description: Required for tiled backgrounds. Indicates the maximum zoom level. Zoom starts at 0 - fully zoomed out - and increases in integer values from there. Eash successive zoom level is twice the zoom of the previous level, meaning two times as many tiles in each direction.

props.name: jsPlumb
props.description:
Optional set of jsPlumb Defaults to use for this renderer. The format and allowed properties is that of
the Defaults object in jsPlumb. You can also set display properties in the view.

props.name: autoExitSelectMode
props.description: When true (which is the default), the Surface will automatically jump back into Pan mode after some nodes have been selected.

props.name: zoomToFit
props.description: If true, content will be zoomed to fit the viewport when a dataLoadEnd event is received.

props.name: zoomToFitIfNecessary
props.description: If true, content will be zoomed to fit the viewport, if necessary (meaning if it fits inside the viewport already it wont be zoomed, which is different from how `zoomToFit` works) when a dataLoadEnd event is received. If this and `zoomToFit` are both set, this takes precedence.

props.name: storePositionsInModel
props.description: By default, the left/top positions of nodes that have been dragged will be written into the data for each node after drag stops. You can set this to false to disable that behaviour.

props.name: modelLeftAttribute
props.description: Optional; specifies the name of the attribute by which to store the x position of a dragged node of `storePositionsInModel` is true.

props.name: modelTopAttribute
props.description: Optional; specifies the name of the attribute by which to store the y position of a dragged node of `storePositionsInModel` is true.

props.name: assignPosse
props.description: optional function that, given each node, can return the id of the posse to which the node belongs. a Posse is a group of nodes that should all be dragged together.

params.name: [params.zoomRange=[0.05,
params.description: 3] ] Zoom range for the widget.

classitems.description:
Generates a debounce helper for the given function, with the given timeout. The given function will be called only
when a period of length `timeout` has elapsed since the last call to the debounce function. Use this for stuff like
relayout of your UI when the window is resized, or firing an ajax call after a series of checkboxes have been
selected or deselected.
classitems.name: jsPlumbToolkitUtil.debounce

params.name: fn
params.description: Function to fire

params.name: timeout
params.description: Timeout, in milliseconds. Default is 150.

return.description: a function with debouncing built in.

classitems.description:
Sets whether or not rendering is suspended. This actually does not mean that new nodes are not
added, but it does mean that the panzoom widget is informed not to do any work involving element
postions or sizes.

Wraps the underlying Toolkit's `batch` function with the added step of first suspending events being
fired from this renderer.

classitems.description:
Activates the UI state with the given ID on the objects contained in the given target. If target is not supplied, the state is
activated against the entire dataset.

params.name: stateId
params.description: ID of the state to activate. States are defined inside a `states` member of your `view` definition.

params.name: target
params.description: Set of objects to activate the state on. If null, the entire dataset (Nodes, Edges and Ports) is used. If you provide an Element here, a Selection is created that consists of the Node representing the element, plus all Edges to and from the given Node.

classitems.description:
Magnetize the display. You must indicate what sort of magnetization you wish to perform: if you provide an event,
the event's location will be the magnetization origin. If you provide `origin:{left;xxx, top:xxx}`, that value will be used. If
you provide neither, the computed center of all elements will be used. You can also provide an `options:{...}` value, whose
values can contain `filter`, `constrain` and `padding` values for the specific run of the magnetizer.

params.name: params
params.description: Magnetize parameters. If omitted, the origin of magnetization will be the computed center of all the elements.

props.name: event
props.description: If provided, the event location will be used as the origin of magnetization.

props.name: origin
props.description: An object with `left` and `top` properties. If provided, will be used as the origin of magnetization.

props.name: options
props.description: Extra magnetizer options for this run of the magnetizer.

classitems.description: Incrementally update the layout, without a reset. If rendering is suspended, this method does nothing.
classitems.name: refresh

classitems.description: Sets whether or not the layout is refreshed automatically after a Node or Port is added or removed.
classitems.name: setRefreshAutomatically

params.name: refreshAutomatically
params.description: True to refresh automatically, false otherwise.

classitems.description: Reset the layout and run it again.  This is different to `refresh` in that `refresh` does not reset the layout first.
classitems.name: relayout

params.name: newParameters
params.description: Optional new parameters for the layout.

classitems.description:
Gets a Path from some source Node/Port to some target Node/Port. This method is a wrapper around the
Toolkit's `getPath` method, adding a `setVisible` function to the result.

params.name: params
params.description: Path spec params

props.name: source
props.description: Source node or port, or id of source node/port

props.name: target
props.description: Target node or port, or id of target node/port

props.name: strict
props.description: Sets whether or not paths are searched strictly by the given source/target. If, for instance, you supply a node as the source, but there are only edges connected to ports on that node, by default these edges will be ignored. Switching `strict` to false will mean these edges are considered.

props.name: nodeFilter
props.description: Optional function that is given each Node's backing data and asked to return true or false - true means include the Node, false means exclude it.

props.name: edgeFilter
props.description: Optional function that is given each Edge's backing data and asked to return true or false - true means include the Edge, false means exclude it.

return.description: a Path object. Even if no path exists you will get a return value - but it will just be empty.

classitems.description:
Writes the current left/top for each node into the data model. A common use case is to run an auto layout the first time
some dataset is seen, and then to save the locations of all the nodes once a human being has moved things around.
classitems.name: storePositionsInModel

params.name: params
params.description: Parameters

props.name: leftAttribute
props.description: Name of the attribute to use for the left position. Default is 'left'

props.name: topAttribute
props.description: Name of the attribute to use for the top position. Default is 'top'

classitems.description:
Writes the current left/top for some node into the data model. A common use case is to run an auto layout the first time
some dataset is seen, and then to save the locations of all the Nodes once a human being has moved things around. Note that this method
takes either a String, representing the Node's ID, and uses the default values for left/top attribute names, or an Object, in which
you provide the id and the left/top attribute names.
classitems.name: storePositionInModel

params.name: id
params.description: ID of the node for which to store the position. Either supply this, or an object containing id and values for the left/top attribute names.

params.name: params
params.description: Parameters. An object containing id and values for the left/top attribute names. Supply this or just supply the node id as a string.

props.name: id
props.description: node id

props.name: leftAttribute
props.description: Name of the attribute to use for the left position. Default is 'left'.

props.name: topAttribute
props.description: Name of the attribute to use for the top position. Default is 'top'.

return.description: The current position as [left, top].

classitems.description: Add the given Node to the posse with the given name

params.name: posse

params.name: active

If true (which is the default), the Node causes all other Nodes in the Posse
to be dragged. If false, this Node drags independently but is dragged whenever an _active_ member of the Posse

classitems.description:
Sets the posse(s) for the element with the given id, creating those that do not yet exist, and removing from
the element any current Posses that are not specified by this method call. This method will not change the
active/passive state if it is given a posse in which the element is already a member.
classitems.name: setPosse

params.name: el
params.description: Element to set posse(s) on.

params.name: spec
params.description:
Variable args parameters. Each argument can be a either a String, indicating
the ID of a Posse to which the element should be added as an active participant, or an Object containing
`{ id:"posseId", active:false/true}`. In the latter case, if `active` is not provided it is assumed to be
true.

If, for instance, you supply a node as the source, but there are only edges connected to ports on that node, by default these edges will be ignored. Switching `strict` to false will mean these edges are considered.

params.description: Optional function that is given each Edge's backing data and asked to return true or false - true means include the Edge, false means exclude it.

An array like `[  \, \{ vertex,cost,edge \} ... ]` when successful; when unsuccessful the three compiled
tables are returned - distances to nodes, each node's previous node, and the associated edge.  so you can call this method with
no target set and get the entire table populated.

datatype you will need to provide one of these to support this functionality. See the documentation on data loading for a full
discussion.

classitems.description:
Sets the type of the given object. This will do two things:
1. update the appropriate propprty in the object's data to this new value. You can set what properties define
types, but by default each of Node, Edge and Port use `type` as the property that indicates their type.
2. attempt to apply a type definition for the new type, if one is found. NB this only applies to Edge objects,
as at version 1.1.0. Support for Nodes (including switching node templates) is a possible future enhancement.

Adds a Node with the given data. If the data is null, the Toolkit creates an empty object and assigns
a uuid as the Node's id.  If no id can be derived for the given data, the Toolkit creates a uuid and
sets it as the data object's 'id' member. This method also calls the current `portExtractor` function, if
one was supplied. Its purpose is to extract any Ports from the data for some given Node.
classitems.name: addNode

params.name: data
params.description: The Node's backing data - from your data model.

params.name: eventInfo
params.description:
Optional data member that the Toolkit will pass into any registered event listeners. This can be used
by the UI layer, for instance, to track the position on screen of any newly added elements.

return.description: A Node object.  Your original data is available via the `data` member. The Node's id is available via the `id` member.

classitems.description:
Adds a Node by type, running the data generation for the node through the current NodeFactory.  This is
different from `addNode` in that with `addNode` you are supplying the final data and your NodeFactory is
not called. This method can be called with one, two or three arguments. A single argument is considered to be
the new Node's `type`, and a backing data object will be created with this set, and no callback will occur.
If you provide two arguments the second argument may be either the new Node's backing data OR a callback to
hit with the newly created Node. With three arguments the second argument is the Node's backing data and the
third is a callback to hit with the newly created Node.

params.name: type
params.description: Required. Type of the object to create. `type` will be passed as the first argument to your node factory.

params.name: data
params.description: Optional backing data for the Node.

params.name: callback
params.description: Optional function to call with the newly created Node.

classitems.description:
Configures the given element as a renderer, registering it so that it reflects any changes to the
underlying data. This method turns the given element into a Surface if it is not already one.  If there is any data in the
Toolkit at the time of this call it is rendered; any data subsequently loaded is automatically rendered. You can supply
layout arguments to this method (layout type + layout specific parameters), as well as jsPlumb rules for
endpoints, paint styles etc.
classitems.name: render

params.name: params
params.description: Method parameters

props.name: container
props.description: Element to convert into a Surface.

props.name: id
props.description: Optional id to register the created Surface against. You can then retrieve the Surface via `toolkit.getRenderer(id)`. If you do not provide this, one will be assigned. The ID is written as the renderer's `id` property.

props.name: elementsDraggable
props.description: Whether or not elements in the Surface should be draggable.

props.name: dragOptions
props.description: Options for draggable elements.

props.name: events
props.description: Optional event bindings. See documentation.

props.name: miniview
props.description: Optional miniview configuration. See documentation.

props.name: mode
props.description: Mode to initialize the Surface in.

props.name: panDistance
props.description: How far a pan nudge should move the UI (in pixels).

props.name: enablePan
props.description: Whether or not panning (via mouse drag) is enabled.

props.name: enableWheelZoom
props.description: Whether or not zooming with the mouse wheel is enabled.

props.name: wheelFilter
props.description: Optional CSS selector representing elements that should not respond to wheel zoom.

props.name: wheelSensitivity
props.description: How many pixels each click of the mouse wheel represents when zooming. Note that this value, while expressed in pixels, is mapped in a variety of ways depending on the browser.

props.name: enablePanButtons
props.description: Whether or not to show the pan nudge buttons on the borders of the widgets.

props.name: padding
props.description:
Optional values for padding in the x/y axes to leave around the content. This is only of any use if you have disabled panning via mouse drag,
since in that case the user sees only scroll bars and has no way of navigating beyond the content. Some padding makes the UI nicer to use. Default is [0,0].

props.name: lassoFilter
props.description: Optional selector for elements on which a mousedown should not cause the lasso to activate.

props.name: consumeRightClick
props.description: Useful for development: set this to false if you don't want the widget to consume context menu clicks.

props.name: jsPlumb
props.description:
Optional set of jsPlumb Defaults to use for this renderer. The format and allowed properties is that of
                the Defaults object in jsPlumb. You can also set display properties in the model.

props.name: enhancedModel
props.description: If false, there will be no support for preconfigured parameters or functions in the definitions inside a Model. You will want to set this for Angular if you use the 2-way data binding.

classitems.description:
Magnetize the display. You must indicate what sort of magnetization you wish to perform: if you provide an event,
the event's location will be the magnetization origin. If you provide `origin:{left;xxx, top:xxx}`, that value will be used. If
you provide neither, the computed center of all elements will be used. You can also provide an `options:{...}` value, whose
values can contain `filter`, `constrain` and `padding` values for the specific run of the magnetizer.

params.name: params
params.description: Magnetize parameters. If ommitted, the origin of magnetization will be the computed center of all the elements.

props.description: If provided, the event location will be used as the origin of magnetization.

props.name: origin
props.description: An object with `left` and `top` properties. If provided, will be used as the origin of magnetization.

props.name: options
props.description: Extra magnetizer options for this run of the magnetizer.

note this method does a 'pass by reference' thing as the return value - any changes you make will
be used by the final layout step (this is a good thing). Note that here it is fine to work with
the node's id, as we are not going anywhere near a DOM element yet. When it comes time to
actually set a DOM element's position, we use the supplied `getElementForNode` function to

classitems.description:
Zooms the display so that all the tracked elements fit inside the viewport. This method will also,
by default, increase the zoom if necessary - meaning the default behaviour is to adjust the zoom so that
the content fills the viewport. You can suppress zoom increase by setting `doNotZoomIfVisible:true` on the
parameters to this method.

Amount of the viewport to fill. By default, this method will zoom so that the content is 0.9 times the size of the viewport.
Aesthetically this makes for a more pleasing result than filling the viewport entirely.

classitems.description:
Sets (or clears) the filter that will be called if the widget needs to know whether to respond to an event that would
start a pan. By default, the widget responds to down events on the viewport or the canvas, but not on child nodes. You
can supply a function that the widget will call in the event that the down event did not occur on the viewport or the canvas;
returning true from this function will cause the pan to begin.
classitems.name: setFilter

params.name: filterFn
params.description: Function to set as the filter; may be null if you wish to clear it. The function should return true if it wants to honour the down event on the given element.

classitems.description: Position the widget so the background is centered in the viewport, without changing the current zoom.

Positions the widget so that the edges of the background align with the viewport. This method is useful for
snapping to a corner of the background.

params.name: axes
params.description:
Spec for the axes to align to. This should be a space-separated string containing a value
for the x (allowed values `left` and `right`) and, optionally, y (allowed values `top` and `bottom`) axes. The
default value is `"left top"`.

classitems.description:
Places (using `style.left` and `style.top`) the given element at the given x,y, which is taken to
mean an x,y value on the canvas.  At zoom 1, with no panning, this will be the same as the given x,y value
relative to the viewport origin.  But once the canvas has been zoomed and panned we have to map
to the altered coordinates. This function also takes into account the difference between the offset of the
viewport in the page and the offset of the given element. It is assumed, just because of what this method
does, that the given element will be positioned `absolute`, but this method does nothing to ensure that.
classitems.name: positionElementAt

params.name: el
params.description: Element to position.

params.name: x
params.description: X location on canvas to move element's left edge to.

params.name: y
params.description: Y location on canvas to move element's top edge to.

params.name: xShift
params.description: Optional absolute number of pixels to shift the element by in the x axis after calculating its position relative to the canvas. Typically you'd use this to place something other than the top left corner of your element at the desired location.

params.name: yShift
params.description: Optional absolute number of pixels to shift the element by in the y axis after calculating its position relative to the canvas.

params.name: ensureOnScreen
params.description: If true, will ensure that x and y positions are never negative.

classitems.description:
Places (using `style.left` and `style.top`) the given element at the given page x,y.  It is assumed, just because of what this method

params.name: yShift

classitems.description:

Amount to change zoom by. The value you pass in here is multiplied by

things.  This function can be used in conjunction with the content bounds by widgets such as the miniview, to calculate what is actually visible in the
viewport at some point in time.

classitems.description:
Finds all nodes that intersect to any extent the rectangle defined by the given origin
and dimensions. This rectangle is taken to be in the coordinate space of the page, ie. a value
of [0,0] for the origin means the page's top/left corner. A future version could take an optional
third argument specifying the element whose origin to use.
classitems.name: findIntersectingNodes

params.name: origin
params.description: [x,y] location for center of search. IMPORTANT: This is relative to the page origin.

params.name: dimensions
params.description: Width and height of search area.

params.name: enclosed
params.description: If true, returns only nodes that are enclosed by the given search area. Otherwise returns nodes that both intersect and are enclosed.

params.name: filter
params.description: Optional filter function. This is passed the (id, node, boundingRect) of some element and should return true for elements that should be included in results.

return.description: A list of objects containing {id:id, el:element, r:bounding rect} that either intersect or are enclosed by the search area.

classitems.description:
Finds all nodes whose centers are within a rectangle with `origin` as its center, and
a width and height of `radius / 2`.

params.name: origin
params.description: [x,y] location for center of search. IMPORTANT: This is relative to the page origin.

params.description: Radius of search.

params.description: If true, first check that the given origin is within the viewport.

params.name: filter
params.description: Optional filter function. Should return true for elements that should be included in results.

return.description: A list of objects containing {id:id, el:element, r:bounding rect}, sorted in ascending order of distance of the center of the bounding rectangle from the given origin.

set this to be "absolute", which means that at the maximum zoom level the number of tiles in each axis
is computed as the size of the image in that axis divided by the tile size in that axis (rounded up of course).
Then at subsequent levels below, the

classitems.description:
Models a Path - the series of edges and intermediate nodes between two nodes or ports
in some toolkit of the Toolkit.

props.description: Sets whether or not paths are searched strictly by the given source/target. If, for toolkit, you supply a node as the source, but there are only edges connected to ports on that node, by default these edges will be ignored. Switching `strict` to false will mean these edges are considered.

classitems.description:
Iterates through the path one step at a time. Each step consists of an object containing a
`vertex`, and, for all entries except the first, an `edge` member, which supplies the Edge that links
to the Vertex (which is why it is null for the first entry).

classitems.description:
Sets the maximum number of nodes the selection can hold. The action taken when appending a node that would
take the selection above its limit depends on the current `capacityPolicy`, which can be either
Selection.DISCARD_EXISTING (the default) or Selection.DISCARD_NEW.

Sets the maximum number of edges the selection can hold. The action taken when appending an edge that would
take the selection above its limit depends on the current `capacityPolicy`, which can be either
Selection.DISCARD_EXISTING (the default) or Selection.DISCARD_NEW.

take the selection above its limit for that given type. Depends on the current `capacityPolicy`,
which can be either `jsPlumbToolkitUtil.Selection.DISCARD_EXISTING` (the default) or `jsPlumbToolkitUtil.Selection.DISCARD_NEW`.

params.name: policy
params.description:
One of `jsPlumbToolkitUtil.Selection.DISCARD_EXISTING` (which removes the 0th entry from the list
before insertion of the new value) or `jsPlumbToolkitUtil.Selection.DISCARD_NEW`.

classitems.description: Clears this selection.
classitems.name: clear

classitems.description:
Reloads the content of this Selection, if a `generator` was supplied to the constructor. Otherwise
does nothing. A data load start event is fired first, followed by a call to the generator to repopulate,
and then a data load end event is fired.  So calling this method on a Selection that you are rendering
to a Surface will cause the Surface to repaint itself.

classitems.description:
Ingests an existing jsPlumb instance into a new Toolkit instance, and turns the instance's Container into a Surface.  Every element
that is the source or target of a Connection is added to the Toolkit instance as a Node, and every Connection is added as an Edge. You
can provide your own functions for determining the `id` and `type` of Nodes and Edges, if you need to. This method will throw an error
if your jsPlumb instance does not have a Container set; it is a requirement for the Surface widget.
classitems.name: ingest

params.name: params
params.description: Method parameters.

props.name: jsPlumb
props.description: The instance of jsPlumb to ingest. If null, it uses the static jsPlumb window instance.

props.name: nodeSelector
props.description: Optional selector to identify elements that may not yet be managed by jsPlumb but which you would like to have imported as Nodes.

props.name: idFunction
props.description:
A function to use to extract the id from elements that are being loaded as Nodes. If null,
                                      the default behaviour is to ask the jsPlumb instance for the element's `id` attribute.

props.name: typeFunction
props.description:
A function to use to extract the type from elements that are being loaded as Nodes. If null,
                                      the default behaviour is to use `default` as the Node type.

props.name: edgeIdFunction
props.description:
A function to use to extract the id from Connections that are being loaded as Edges. If null,
                                      the default behaviour is to use the Connection's `id`.

props.name: edgeTypeFunction
props.description:
A function to use to extract the type from Connections that are being loaded as Edges. If null,
                                      the default behaviour is to use `default` as the Edge type.

props.name: renderParams
props.description: Parameters to pass to the Surface constructor.

props.name: render
props.description: If false, this method returns only a Toolkit instance with data loaded, and doesn't create a Surface renderer for it.

return.description: A Surface instance whose underlying Toolkit has been loaded with the contents of the jsPlumb instance (you can access the Toolkit itself via `surface.getToolkit()`), or, if `render` was set to false, a `jsPlumbToolkitInstance`..

the content fills the viewport. You can suppress zoom increase by setting `doNotZoomIfVisible:true` on the
parameters to this method.

classitems.description:
Returns the apparent [left,top] of the canvas inside the viewport - the coordinates, in real pixel
values, of where the origin of the canvas appears to be. This apparent origin is not necessarily the
same as the [left,top] values of the canvas, because the transform origin and zoom values change
things.  This function can be used in conjunction with the content bounds by widgets such as the miniview,
to calculate what is actually visible in the viewport at some point in time.

Sets the current zoom range. By default, this method checks if the current zoom is within

value that was ultimately set is returned from this function. The value you pass in here is multiplied by

classitems.description:
Finds all nodes that intersect to any extent the rectangle defined by the given origin
and dimensions. This rectangle is taken to be in the coordinate space of the document, ie. a value
of [0,0] for the origin means the document's top/left corner. A future version could take an optional
third argument specifying the element whose origin to use.
classitems.name: findIntersectingNodes

params.name: dimensions
params.description: Width and height of search area.

params.description: If true, returns only nodes that are enclosed by the given search area. Otherwise returns nodes that both intersect and are enclosed.

return.description: A list of objects containing {id:id, el:element, r:bounding rect} that either intersect or are enclosed by the search area.

classitems.description:
Places (using `style.left` and `style.top`) the given element at the given x,y, which is taken to
mean an [x,y] value on the canvas.  At zoom 1, with no panning, this will be the same as the given [x,y] value
relative to the viewport origin.  But once the canvas has been zoomed and panned we have to map
to the altered coordinates. This function also takes into account the difference between the offset of the
viewport in the page and the offset of the given element. It is assumed, just because of what this method
does, that the given element will be positioned `absolute`, but this method does nothing to ensure that.
Note that this method - and its relatives, `positionElementAtEventLocation` and `positionElementAtPageLocation` - are
not intended for use with elements being managed by the Surface. They are for use with external
elements that you need to align with the contents of the Surface.
classitems.name: positionElementAt

params.name: el
params.description: Element to position.

params.name: x
params.description: X location on canvas to move element's left edge to.

params.name: y
params.description: Y location on canvas to move element's top edge to.

params.name: xShift
params.description: Optional absolute number of pixels to shift the element by in the x axis after calculating its position relative to the canvas. Typically you'd use this to place something other than the top left corner of your element at the desired location.

params.name: yShift
params.description: Optional absolute number of pixels to shift the element by in the y axis after calculating its position relative to the canvas.

`positionElementAt` and `positionElementAtPageLocation` - are not intended for use with elements being
managed by the Surface. They are for use with external elements that you need to align with the contents
of the Surface.

classitems.description:
Sets (or clears) the filter that will be called if the widget needs to know whether to respond to an event that would
start a pan. By default, the widget responds to down events on the viewport or the canvas, but not on child nodes. You
can supply a function that the widget will call in the event that the down event did not occur on the viewport or the canvas;
returning true from this function will cause the pan to begin.
classitems.name: setFilter

params.name: filterFn
params.description: Function to set as the filter; may be null if you wish to clear it. The function should return true if it wants to honour the down event on the given element.

Appends an element to the viewport so that it floats above the content that is being zoomed and panned.
The element will have `position:absolute` set on it. You can float any element you like, but note that the
responsibility for setting an appropriate z index is yours.

params.description: Element to float.

params.name: pos
params.description: Array of [x,y] positions.

classitems.description:
Traces the given overlay along either a given path, or the shortest path
from a specified `source` to a specified `target` (if such a path exists).
If there is no path nothing happens (except for a debug trace, if you have debugging enabled on
the Toolkit instance via `toolkit.setDebugEnabled(true)`)

params.name: params
params.description: Options for the trace.

props.name: path
props.description: Path to trace.

props.name: source
props.description: Source of traversal. May be a Node or Port, or a DOM element or element id. Supply this if you do not supply `path`.

props.name: target
props.description: Target of traversal. May be a Node or Port, or a DOM element or element id. Supply this if you do not supply `path`.

props.name: overlay
props.description: This is in the format accepted by the Community edition of jsPlumb.

props.name: options
props.description: Options for animation.

props.name: dwell
props.description: How long, in milliseconds, to dwell on each node as the overlay traverses the path.

props.name: speed
props.description: How many pixels per second to travel. *Note*: this is in seconds, not milliseconds.

props.name: rate
props.description: Frame rate, in milliseconds.

return.description: True if the path existed and was traced. False otherwise.

classitems.description:
Selects a set of edges. If you supply a DOM element for any of the arguments here, the underlying graph object - a Node or a Port - will be
determined, and the edges for that object will be retrieved.  Note that for a Port this method does the same thing as
`selectAllEdges`, but for a Node, which may have Ports registered on it, this method will retrieve only the Edges directly
registered on the Node itself.  You may need to use `selectAllEdges` if you want everything from some Node.

props.description: Source or target node, as a Node, a DOM element, a selector, or a String (including support for wildcard '*')

classitems.description:
Allows you to register a list of droppables that can be dropped onto the surface. This function also supports
configuring the Surface to accept files dragged from the user's desktop, but it is limited to supporting one file
at a time.
classitems.name: registerDroppableNodes

params.name: params
params.description: Parameters for droppables, including node list, drop options etc

props.name: typeExtractor
props.description: Optional function to use to extract the related node type for some element that was dropped on the Surface.

props.name: dataGenerator
props.description: Optional function to use to generate some initial data for a node of some given type. The function is passed `type` as argument, which _may be null_, so program defensively.

props.name: droppables
props.description:
List of elements identifying the elements to be configured as droppable. Either provide this,
or provide `source` and `selector`. It is only in this latter case that you will be able to call `refresh` to
subsequently add newly added elements to the set of droppables.

props.name: source
props.description:
Source element on which to execute `querySelectorAll` with the given `selector`
in order to get the list of elements to be configured as droppable.

props.name: selector
props.description: Selector that specifies child nodes of `source` that should be configured as droppable.

props.name: dragOptions
props.description: Optional set of drag options, in a format specific to your underlying library.

props.name: dropOptions
props.description: Optional set of drop options, in a format specific to your underlying library.

props.name: start
props.description: Function to call when a droppable starts to be dragged.

props.name: drag
props.description: Function to call as a droppable is being dragged.

props.name: stop
props.description: Function to call when a droppable stops being dragged.

props.name: drop
props.description: Function to call when a droppable has been dropped, *before* the Toolkit code is run. Returning false from this function causes the drop to be aborted.

classitems.description: Gets the current Miniview, if there is one. There may not be.
classitems.name: getMiniview

return.description: Current Miniview, null if no Miniview is registered.

classitems.description:
Writes the current location of each node in the UI to local storage (using either a cookie or html5 storage,
depending on browser capabilities). You pass this function a 'handle' argument, which is used to restore the state
at some stage in the future.
classitems.name: State.save

params.name: handle
params.description: The handle to save the state as, If this is not supplied, and `stateHandle` was supplied as a constructor parameter, that is used instead.

params.name: preprocessor
params.description: Optional preprocessor which is given the serialized state, and a callback function, before saving to localStorage. Useful if you wish to compress the data, for instance.

classitems.description: Serializes the UI state to a String.
classitems.name: State.serialize

classitems.description:
Restores the UI state to the state it was in when it was saved with the given handle. If the handle does not
exist, nothing happens. It is possible a future incarnation of this could support animating a UI back to some state.
classitems.name: State.restore

params.name: handle
params.description: The handle to restore the state from, If this is not supplied, and `stateHandle` was supplied as a constructor parameter, that is used instead.

params.name: preprocessor
params.description: Optional preprocessor which is given the serialized state before saving to localStorage. Useful if you wish to compress the data, for instance.

classitems.description: Restores the UI state to the serialized state given.
classitems.name: State.deserialize

params.name: value
params.description: Serialized state.

classitems.description: Clears the state that was stored against the given handle.
classitems.name: State.clear

classitems.description: Removes all saved UI state information.
classitems.name: State.clearAll

classitems.description: Saves the current state of the UI, either to local storage or a cookie, depending on the browser's capabilities.
classitems.name: saveState

params.name: handle
params.description: The handle to save the state as, If this is not supplied, and `stateHandle` was supplied as a constructor parameter, that is used instead.

classitems.description: Restores the current state of the UI, either from local storage or a cookie, depending on the browser's capabilities.
classitems.name: restoreState

params.name: handle
params.description: The handle to restore the state from, If this is not supplied, and `stateHandle` was supplied as a constructor parameter, that is used instead.

classitems.description: Clears the state stored by the given handle.
classitems.name: clearState

params.name: handle
params.description: The handle to restore the state from. If this is not supplied, and `stateHandle` was supplied as a constructor parameter, that is used instead.

classitems.description:
Serialize an instance of jsPlumb to a single SVG element. This is added to the prototype
of jsPlumbInstance as `toSvg`.

This takes an svg path element and copies it. A path element passed in here has a parent that has
positioning information, but we want to move that positioning info into the path element, using
the `transform` attribute. it is possible (likely, even) that a path passed in here already has a
transform, so we read that and add it to our desired values if we find it.
functionality to support template loading from script tags (browser only)

Missing item type
Gets the type of the given Object. This is not a type such as `Node`, `Port` or `Edge` - this is the type of the
object as defined by your system to identify types; these are the types used to lookup objects in the view.

Missing item type
Sets the type of the given object. This will do two things:
1. update the appropriate propprty in the object's data to this new value. You can set what properties define
types, but by default each of Node, Edge and Port use `type` as the property that indicates their type.
2. attempt to apply a type definition for the new type, if one is found. NB this only applies to Edge objects,
as at version 1.1.0. Support for Nodes (including switching node templates) is a possible future enhancement.

Missing item type
Adds a Node by type, running the data generation for the node through the current NodeFactory.  This is
different from `addNode` in that with `addNode` you are supplying the final data and your NodeFactory is
not called. This method can be called with one, two or three arguments. A single argument is considered to be
the new Node's `type`, and a backing data object will be created with this set, and no callback will occur.
If you provide two arguments the second argument may be either the new Node's backing data OR a callback to
hit with the newly created Node. With three arguments the second argument is the Node's backing data and the
third is a callback to hit with the newly created Node.

Missing item type
Suspends rendering and then runs the given function, unsuspending rendering afterwards and doing
a refresh. This method is just a convenience method that handles suspending
and subsequent enabling of rendering. You might use this if you're adding a whole load of Nodes or
Edges, or maybe you want to add a Node and one or more Edges before
the layout recomputes.
